questions.text: All Trans’ retinoic acid is used in the treatment of tumor associated with?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PML-RARA All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of tumors associated with B. PML-RARA. PML-RARA is a fusion gene resulting from a chromosomal translocation between the PML gene on chromosome 15 and the RARA gene on chromosome 17. This translocation is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). ATRA is a derivative of vitamin A a nd acts as a differentiating agent in APL treatment. It binds to the abnormal PML-RARA protein, promoting the differentiation of leukemia cells into mature granulocytes, and inducing remission in APL patients.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. BCR-ABL: This fusion gene is associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), and the standard treatment for CML involves tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) such as imatinib, not ATRA. Option C. cMYC: cMYC is a proto-oncogene that can be involved in the development of various cancers, but ATRA is not the specific treatment for cMYC-associated tumors. Option D. CEBPA: CEBPA is a transcription factor gene, and mutations in this gene are associated with a specific subtype of AML. ATRA is not the primary treatment for AML with CEBPA mutations.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman came with complaints of easy fatigability, exertion dyspnea and weight loss. She also complaints of Frequent fall. Physical Examination revealed there was bilateral decrease in vibration sense. Her hemoglobin levels were 8.2gm%. She was treated with folate. Her anemia improved but neurological symptoms worsened. Which of the following is the most probable reason for her condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS

options.label: D
options.text: Folate therapy caused rapid use of B12 Stores aggravating Symptoms

questions.correct_answer: D. Folate therapy caused rapid use of B12 Stores aggravating Symptoms
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Folate therapy caused rapid use of B12 Stores aggravating Symptoms Vitamin B12 The most probable reason for the worsening of neurological symptoms in this patient despite the improvement of anemia with folate therapy is D. Folate therapy caused rapid use of B12 stores aggravating symptoms.

Highyeild:

Folate and Vitamin B12 deficiency causing Megaloblastic anemia The patient's clinical presentation o f easy fatigability, exertion dyspnea, weight loss, bilateral decrease in vibration sense, and hemoglobin level of 8.2 gm % are consistent with megaloblastic anemia, which can be caused by deficiencies of either vitamin B12 (cobalamin) or folate. Folate (vitamin B9) and vitamin B12 (cobalamin) are both essential for DNA synthesis and red blood cell maturation. They play crucial roles in the formation of healthy red blood cells. Folate deficiency can lead to megaloblastic anemia, which is characterized by large, immature red blood cells. When a patient with vitamin B12 deficiency (pernicious anemia) is treated with folate alone, it can improve the anemia, but it may mask the underlying vitamin B12 deficiency. Folate therapy can correct the megaloblastic anemia caused by folate deficiency but does not address the neurological symptoms associated with vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to neurological problems due to demyelination of nerves, resulting in sensory and motor disturbances. Prolonged vitamin B12 deficiency can cause irreversible nerve damage.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Folate not absorbed: If folate was not absorbed, the anemia would not have improved with folate therapy. Option B. Unmasked pyridoxine deficiency: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency is not the primary cause of megaloblastic anemia, and its unmasking would not explain the neurological symptoms. Option C. Deficiency of folate reductase in the CNS: Deficiency of folate reductase in the central nervous system would not be the cause of worsening neurological symptoms in the context of folate therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following factors play a major role in initiation of thrombus formation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endothelial injury The major factor that plays a key role in the initiation of thrombus formation is D. Endothelial injury. The endothelium is the inner lining of blood vessels and serves as a protective barrier between the blood and the vessel wall . When the endothelium is damaged due to various reasons, such as trauma, inflammation, or atherosclerosis, it exposes the underlying subendothelial tissue. The exposed subendothelial tissue contains collagen and other procoagulant substances that are usually not in contact with circulating blood . Once exposed, these substances trigger platelet activation and the coagulation cascade.

Highyeild:

Virchows’s triad in thrombosis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A .Vasoconstriction: Incorrect option Option B .Coagulation cascade activation: Incorrect option Option C .Platelets activation: Incorrect option

questions.text: 33-year-old man presents with a 5-week history of calf pain and swelling and low-grade fever. Serum levels of creatine kinase are elevated. A Muscle biopsy reveals numerous eosinophils. He also has peripheral blood eosinophilia. Which of the following interleukins is primarily responsible for the increase in eosinophils in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IL4 The interleukin primarily responsible for the increase in eosinophils in this patient is B. IL-4. Eosinophils are a type of white blood cell involved in the immune response, particularly against parasitic infections and allergic reactions. Interleukins are signaling proteins that play a crucial role in regulating the immune system and inflammation. IL-4 is known as an interleukin-4 and is produced by T helper 2 (Th2) cells and mast cells. It is a key cytokine involved in promoting the differentiation and activation of eosinophils. IL-4 stimulates the production and release of eosinophils from the bone marrow and enhances their survival in peripheral tissues. Additionally, IL-4 also induces the expression of cell surface receptors on eosinophils, making them more responsive to other proinflammatory signals. Note:- Most potent activator of eosinophil is IL5 > IL4 So, best answer is IL4 here.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A .IL2: Incorrect answer Option C. IL1: Incorrect answer Option D .IL6: Incorrect answer

questions.text: A 45-year old person who is chronic smoker came to the clinic with Complaints of cough. The physician examines the patient and take a biopsy. The picture in the biopsy was as the description below. Which of the following cellular changes has happened in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Metaplasia Here, the picture shows normal pseudostratified epithelium is replaced by squamous epithelium which suggests the diagnosis of Squamous Metaplasia. Metaplasia is a reversible change in which one differentiated cell type is replaced by another cell type that is not normally present in that tissue.

Highyeild:

Cellular adaptations: Term Definition Causes Atrophy Decreased in size and function of the cell -Decreased workload , decreased blood supply,loss of innervation,interruption of trophic signal, aging Hypertrophy Increase in size of cells resulting in increase in size of organ accompanied by an augmented functional capacity -Increased functional demand eg: myocardial hypertrophy in hypertension, muscle hypertrophy in athletes -Physiologic (hormonal) hypertrophy: eg: sex organs at puberty Hyperplasia Increase in number of cells in an organ or tissue -Increased functional demand e.g: -Increased number of RBCs at high altitude. prostate in elderly men -Hormonal stimulation: endometrium in early phase of menstrual cycle -Persistent cell injury: Skin in calluses Metaplasia A change in one type of adult differentiated cell type to anotherAlthough it is a protective mechanism there may be loss of function -Repeated or persistent stress or injury eg: conversion of bronchial ciliated columnar epithelium to squamous epithelium in smokers Dysplasia Alteration in size,shape and organization of cells characterized by - Variation in size and shape of cells (cellular pleomorphism) - Variation in size and shape of nuclei (nuclear pleomorphism) - Enlargement, Irregularity and hyperchromatism of the nuclei - Disordered arrangement of the cell Persistent injury may lead to dysplasia. Eg: dysplasia in cervical epithelial, dysplasia in bronchial epithelium

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Hyperplasia: It refers to an increase in the number of cells in an organ or tissue, which is not described in the biopsy. Option B. Dysplasia: It is the abnormal development or growth of cells, which can be a precursor to cancer, but it is not mentioned in the biopsy description. Option D. CIN3: It (Cervical Intraepithelial Neoplasia 3) refers to severe dysplasia of the cervical epithelium and is not relevant to the description of the respiratory biopsy.

Solution:

It is a trinucleotide Expansion mutation related disorder The correct statement related to Huntington's Chorea is- It is a trinucleotide Expansion mutation-related disorder. questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with a 2cm thyroid nodule. A thyroidectomy was done. The histology picture is given bellow. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Papillary Carcinoma Thyroid The given clinical scenario and histopathological image showing papillary architecture, where the tumor cells form finger-like projections or papillae and orphan Annie’s eye nuclei suggests the diagnosis of papillary carcinoma thyroid. It accounts for approximately 80% of all thyroid cancers.

Highyeild:

Papillary thyroid carcinoma It is the most common type of thyroid cancer, accounting for about 80% of all cases. Associated with a number of genetic alterations, including BRAF and NTRK1 mutations and RET/PTC rearrangements. Other risk factors: Childhood irradiation and thyroglossal cysts, Family history of thyroid cancer, and certain genetic syndromes such as Cowden syndrome and familial adenomatous polyposis. Histological feature: Papillary architecture Psammoma bodies Nuclear grooves and pseudo inclusions Orphan Annie’s eye nuclei Fibrovascular cores Present as a solitary nodule or as a multifocal disease involving both lobes of the thyroid gland. Prognosis: Excellent: a 10-year survival rate of greater than 95%.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Follicular adenoma: These are benign thyroid nodules that typically present as well-circumscribed encapsulated lesions. They do not exhibit the specific histological features of papillary architecture and orphan Annie eye appearance. Option C. Graves disease: It is an autoimmune disorder that causes hyperthyroidism, resulting in diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland (diffuse goiter). It does not typically present as a solitary thyroid nodule. Option D. Adenomatous goiter: It refers to the presence of multiple nodules within the thyroid gland. It does not usually present as a solitary thyroid nodule, and the histological features described are not consistent with adenomatous goiter.

questions.text: A 30-year-old came with complaints of thyroid swelling. On investigations her TSH levels were found to be elevated. Post-Operative HPE reports Showed lymphocytic infiltration and Hurthle cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hashimoto thyroiditis The given clinical scenario including the complaint of thyroid swelling, elevated TSH levels, and the histopathological findings of lymphocytic infiltration and Hurthle cells , suggests the diagnosis of Hashimoto thyroiditis. It is an autoimmune condition that causes inflammation of the thyroid gland.

Highyeild:

Hashimoto thyroiditis Aka chronic autoimmune thyroiditis A most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient regions. Associated with HLA-DR3 Increased risk of primary thyroid lymphoma- diffuse large B-cell lymphoma Features: Moderately enlarged, non-tender thyroid May be preceded by transient hyperthyroid state: Hashitoxicosis due to follicular rupture Serology: Antithyroid peroxidase and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies present Histology: Hurthle cells , lymphoid aggregates with germinal centres Treatment: Toxic phase: Beta-blocker Hypothyroid state: T4 supplements

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Graves disease: It is an autoimmune condition that causes hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism. It is characterized by diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland and is associated with low or suppressed TSH levels. Option B. Follicular thyroiditis: Aka subacute thyroiditis. It is an inflammatory condition that presents with a painful, tender thyroid gland. It is typically associated with transient hyperthyroidism followed by hypothyroidism. Option D. Medullary Carcinoma thyroid: It is a rare type of thyroid cancer that arises from the parafollicular or C cells of the thyroid. It typically presents as a solitary nodule or mass and is associated with elevated calcitonin levels.

questions.text: Which of the following disease will have irregular, bulky, and friable cardiac vegetations?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Infective Endocarditis The disease that will have irregular, bulky, and friable cardiac vegetations is: B. Infective Endocarditis. The cardiac vegetations in infective endocarditis are composed of fibrin, platelets, microorganisms, and inflammatory cells. These vegetation can vary in size, shape, and appearance but are often described as irregular, bulky, and friable. https://images.app.goo.gl/KtUQJKFVmYCMivwNA

Highyeild:

Infective or bacterial endocarditis It is serious infection of the valvular and mural endocardium caused by different forms of microorganisms and is characterized by typical infected and friable vegetations. Depending upon the severity of infection, BE is subdivided into 2 clinical forms:- Acute bacterial endocarditis (ABE) is fulminant and destructive acute infection of the endocardium by highly virulent bacteria in a previously normal heart and almost invariably runs a rapidly fatal course in a period of 2-6 weeks. Subacute bacterial endocarditis (SABE) is caused by less virulent bacteria in a previously diseased heart and has a gradual downhill course in a period of 6 weeks to a few months and sometimes years.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Libman-Sacks endocarditis: This type of endocarditis is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and is characterized by small, sterile vegetations. These vegetations are typically smaller and more delicate compared to the bulky and friable vegetations seen in infective endocarditis. Option C . Rheumatic carditis: It is a complication of rheumatic fever, caused by an immune response to a previous group A Streptococcus infection. It can lead to inflammation of the heart valves and endocardium. While the valves may be affected in rheumatic carditis, the vegetations are not typically described as irregular, bulky, and friable. Option D. NBTE: NBTE is a condition characterized by the formation of sterile, non-infectious, and nonbacterial vegetations on the heart valves. These vegetations are composed of platelets and fibrin but do not contain microorganisms. While they are nonbacterial, the vegetations in NBTE are not specifically described as irregular, bulky, and friable, as seen in infective endocarditis.

During the process of reperfusion, there is an influx of calcium ions into the injured myocardial cells, leading to the formation of eosinophilic bands known as " eosinophilic contraction bands."

While inflammation can occur in post-MI reperfusion injury, neutrophilia in cardiac muscle itself is not a typical histological finding in this condition. Option D. questions.text: A 35-year-old heterosexual patient diagnosed with HIV had history of chronic watery diarrhea. Colonoscopy biopsy is shown as below. Which of the following is your most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cryptosporidium The given clinical scenario of diarrhea in an HIV positive patient and colonic biopsy showing uniformly stained acid-fast oocyst suggests the diagnosis of Cryptosporidium infection. It is a protozoan parasite that can cause gastrointestinal infections, particularly in individuals with compromised immune systems, such as those with HIV/AIDS. It is known to cause chronic watery diarrhea in immunocompromised indivisuals.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Giardia: It is another protozoan parasite that can cause diarrhea, but it does not stain with acid-fast dyes. Giardia is typically identified using specific staining methods such as the Giemsa stain. Option C. Isospora: Isospora is another intestinal parasite that can cause diarrhea, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. The oocyst of isospora are oval and bigger. Option D. CMV: It is a viral infection that can affect various organs, including the gastrointestinal tract. While CMV can be associated with gastrointestinal manifestations, it is not typically identified through acid-fast staining. CMV is usually diagnosed using immunohistochemical staining or molecular techniques.

questions.text: A 5-year old kid presented with history of blood in stools. On examination there was a Polypoidal mass in rectum, biopsy of which is shown as below. Your most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Juvenile polyp The given clinical history and a histopathological image showing dilated glands filled with mucin is suggestive of a Juvenile polyp (retention polyps). Juvenile polyps are the most common type of colorectal polyps in children , and they are usually pedunculated with a smooth surface. Usually <3cm in diameter Histologically, they are characterized by cystically dilated glands lined by normal-appearing epithelium. These polyps are benign and usually do not require any further intervention after polypectomy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Villous adenoma: These are typically larger, flat or sessile polyps with a velvety appearance. They are more commonly found in adults rather than in children. Option C. Vascular malformation: It refers to abnormalities in blood vessels, such as arteriovenous malformations or vascular tumors. The biopsy findings of a polypoidal mass are not consistent with a vascular malformation. Option D. Serrated adenoma: These are a subtype of colorectal polyps that have a distinct histological appearance characterized by saw-toothed or serrated glands.

questions.text: A 30 year old male came with complaints of swelling around the knee joint. Histopathological examination of the swelling demonstrated many giant cells interspersed with mono-nuclear cells. Your most probable diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Giant cell tumor The most probable diagnosis based on the histopathological examination of the swelling with many giant cells interspersed with mono-nuclear cells is: D. Giant cell tumor. The tumour arises in the epiphysis of long bones close to the articular cartilage. Most common sites of involvement are lower end of femur and upper end of tibia (i.e. about the knee), lower end of radius and upper end of fibula. The hallmark features of giant cell tumour are the presence of large number of multinucleate osteoclast like giant cells regularly scattered throughout the stromal mononuclear cells

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that typically presents with aggressive bone destruction and areas of osteoid production. It does not typically exhibit numerous giant cells as seen in the described histopathological examination. Option B. Chondrosarcoma: Chondrosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that arises from cartilage cells. Histologically, it is characterized by the production of malignant cartilaginous matrix. Giant cells are not a typical feature of chondrosarcoma. Option C. Ewing's sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that predominantly occurs in children and young adults. Histologically, it is characterized by small, round, blue cells. Giant cells are not a typical feature of Ewing's sarcoma.

options.label: A

questions.explanation:

30% people have HbsAg Positive The true statement about PAN (Polyarteritis Nodosa) is: C. 30% of people with PAN have HbsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) positive.

Highyeild:

Polyarteritis Nodosa PAN is characterized by necrotizing immune complex inflammation of small- and medium-sized arteries. It is marked by the destruction of arterial media and internal elastic lamella, resulting in aneurysmal nodules. There is an association with hepatitis B viral infection in 30% of patients. Clinical manifestations often include fever, weight loss, malaise, abdominal pain, headache, myalgia, and hypertension. Polyarteritis nodosa is seen in the following sites: Kidneys, with immune complex vasculitis in the arterioles and glomeruli; renal lesions, and hypertension cause most deaths from polyarteritis nodosa. questions.text: A 20- year-old presented to the clinic with history of malabsorption, diarrhea and poor appetite, Vomiting, poor appetite. Duodenal Biopsy of the patient showed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, CD8+ Cells in lamina propria. Your most probable diagnosis is.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Celiac disease The given clinical scenario with history of malabsorption, diarrhoea and duodenal biopsy showing crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in the lamina propria suggests the diagnosis of Celiac disease. It is an autoimmune disorder characterized by an immune reaction to gluten , a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. It primarily affects the small intestine, leading to inflammation, villous atrophy, and crypt hyperplasia.

Highyeild:

Celiac disease Aka Gluten-sensitive enteropathy or celiac sprue Cause: Autoimmune-mediated intolerance to gliadin which is a gluten protein found in the BROW diet (Barley, Rye Oats, Wheat) Genetic: Associated with HLA-DQ2, HLA-DQ8 Site affected: Distal duodenum and/or proximal jejunum Feature: Malabsorption and steatorrhea presenting as diarrhea and weight loss Association: Dermatitis herpetiformis Increased risk of developing T- cell lymphoma Decreased bone density Diagnosis: Abnormal D-xylose test Positive IgA tTG , anti-endomysial and anti-deamidated gliadin peptide antibodies

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Environmental enteropathy: It is also known as tropical enteropathy, is a condition commonly seen in developing countries with poor sanitation and hygiene. It is characterized by chronic intestinal inflammation and structural changes in the small intestine. Option C . Whipple's disease: It is a rare bacterial infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei. It primarily affects the small intestine but can involve other organs as well. Option D . Chronic Pancreatitis: It is a condition characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of the pancreas. It primarily affects the exocrine function of the pancreas, leading to impaired digestion and malabsorption.

Extraedge:

MARSH grading It is used to subclassify celiac disease based on features of Intraepithelial lymphocytes, crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented to the clinic with a 4cm mass in the upper outer quadrant. Biopsy bland nuclei and mucin infiltrating the stroma. Which of the following is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Colloid carcinoma Colloid carcinoma AKA mucinous carcinoma Colloid carcinoma is seen in about 2% cases, occurs more frequently in older women and is slow-growing. Colloid carcinoma has better prognosis than the usual infiltrating duct carcinoma. Grossly- The tumour is usually a soft and gelatinous mass with well-demarcated borders. Colloid carcinoma contains large amount of extracellular epithelial mucin and acini filled with mucin. Cuboidal to tall columnar tumour cells, some showing mucus vacuolation, are seen floating in large lakes of mucin. Abundant mucin production is not a feature of other choices.

questions.text: A 35 year-old woman with a long history of dyspnea, chronic cough, sputum production, and wheezing dies of respiratory failure following a bout of pneumonia. She was not a smoker or alcoholic. The lung at autopsy is shown in the image. Which of the following underlying Conditions was most likely associated with the pathologic changes shown here?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alpha 1 antitrypsin deficiency The given clinical scenario with the history of dyspnea, chronic cough, sputum production, wheezing, and the image showing emphysematous lungs suggests the diagnosis of Alpha 1 antitrypsin deficiency causing Emphysema. In individuals with alpha 1 antitrypsin deficiency, the lack of this protective protein leads to uncontrolled activity of Elastase enzymes , resulting in tissue damage, particularly in the lungs.

Highyeild:

Emphysema Emphysema is a lung disease characterized by the destruction of the alveoli (air sacs) in the lungs , leading to shortness of breath and difficulty breathing. -Risk factors: The most significant risk factor for Emphysema is cigarette smoking Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency Long-term exposure to air pollution and occupational exposure to dust, fumes, and chemicals. -Pathophysiology: -Features: Chronic shortness of breath, chronic cough with scanty sputum production , and reduced exercise tolerance. Wheezing, chest tightness, and weight loss. Barrel-shaped chest Expiration is prolonged and/or through pursed lips Diagnostic tests: Pulmonary function tests: Decreased FEV1/FVC ratio, decreased DLCO, and increased residual volume. Chest X-rays may show hyperinflation of the lungs with flattened diaphragms: Increased lung field lucency

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Mutation in dynein arms: Dynein arms are components of cilia, and mutations in dynein arms are associated with a condition called primary ciliary dyskinesia. PCD primarily affects the respiratory tract and leads to impaired ciliary function. Option B. Cystic fibrosis: It is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the respiratory and digestive systems. It is characterized by the production of thick, sticky mucus, which can obstruct the airways and lead to recurrent lung infections. Option D. Antibodies against type 4 Collagen: These are associated with certain autoimmune disorders, such as Goodpasture syndrome. Goodpasture syndrome primarily affects the kidneys and lungs, causing glomerulonephritis and lung hemorrhage. Emphysema is not a characteristic feature of this condition.

questions.text: A 23 year old male presented to the clinic with history of Fatigue and tiredness. On investigation he was found to have Hb values of -9gm%, MCV OF 101 FL. Peripheral smear examination showed macrocytic RBC and hypersegmented neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely etiology?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chronic alcoholism MCV – 101fl is suggestive of macrocytosis most commonly (especially when the increase in size is mild, and just above normal range) the cause is bone marrow dysplasia secondary to alcohol abuse and chronic alcoholism, Poor absorption of vitamin B12 in the digestive tract can also cause macrocytosis. Macrocytosis is frequently linked to alcoholism, with or without liver disease. In fact, it is purported to be one of the most common causes of non megaloblastic macrocytosis In cases of macrocytosis related to alcoholism the elevated MCV may be due to the direct effect of the alcohol, liver disease and/or folate deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following infection is common within 1- 4 months post transplant?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CMV Transplant patients are among those most vulnerable to CMV infection, especially in the critical few months after the transplant. Between 20% and 60% of people with a solid organ transplant develop a symptomatic CMV infection. These symptoms are similar to the flu – fever, body aches, sore throat – and may be difficult to control. The disease caused by post-transplant CMV (PT-CMV) occurs due to:- Transmission from the transplanted organ, Due to reactivation of latent infection, or After a primary infection in seronegative transplant patients.
